::: {#hero-heading}
Wenbin Hu, Ph.D., is a native of Wuhan, China. He is currently a Professor and Ph.D. Supervisor at the School of Computer Science, Wuhan University, and also serves as a professor at the Institute of Artificial Intelligence, Wuhan University, the Xiaomi–Wuhan University Joint Laboratory of Artificial Intelligence, and the JD–Wuhan University Institute of Trusted Artificial Intelligence. He joined the Postdoctoral Research Station of Computer Science and Technology at Wuhan University in 2006, was awarded the title of Outstanding Postdoctoral Fellow of Wuhan University in 2007, appointed as a Master’s supervisor in 2008, and as a Ph.D. supervisor in 2011. 

His research interests span artificial intelligence and intelligent simulation optimization, generative artificial intelligence, social network modeling and optimization, graph computing and data mining, intelligent computation and decision making, intelligent transportation systems, and computer integrated manufacturing systems. His research have been applied across a broad range of domains, including drug discovery, cross-media intelligence, urban transportation planning, port logistics, e-commerce, power systems, healthcare, and public safety.

Academically, he has published over 100 papers as the first or corresponding author in leading international journals and top-tier conferences, including IEEE TKDE, IEEE TMC, ACM TKDD, IEEE TITS, and IEEE TNNLS, as well as SIGKDD, WWW, IJCAI, AAAI, ACL, and ICDM. He has served as a Program Committee (PC) member for major international conferences such as AAAI and ICDM.




:::
